ere are the extracted triplets:

< Gormond et Isembart
1:
--------------------
Text: Gormond et Isembart:  Along with "The Song of Roland" and the "Chanson de Guillaume", it is one of the three "chansons de geste" whose composition incontestably dates from before 1150; it may be slightly younger than "The Song of Roland" and, according to one expert, may date from as early as 1068.
Triplets:<Gormond et Isembart
2:
--------------------
Text: Gormond et Isembart:  The poem tells the story of a rebellious young French lord, Isembart, who allies himself with a Saracen king, Gormond, renounces his Christianity, and battles the French king.
Triplets:<Gormond
3:
--------------------
Text: Gormond et Isembart:  The poem is sometimes grouped with the "Geste de Doon de Mayence" or "rebellious vassal cycle" of "chansons de geste".
Triplets:<Gormond et Isembart
